course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Innovation Management and Technology Entrepreneurship
course.description: The course focuses on innovation strategies and entrepreneurship skills that provide an intellectual structure for understanding the issues of how entrepreneurial firms recognize potential of an innovation on time, how they implement the right strategies to exploit the innovation, and how to protect their profits from competitors.  The course also explores the increasingly global character of entrepreneurial firms, and how successful technology companies compete across cultures, markets and nations.

reviews.author: B.T.
reviews.title: Idk what have I done after the whole sem
reviews.comment_content:
-Why entrepreneurhsip
-Innovate ideas
-Entreprenuerial uncertainty
-Value Proposition
-Business Model
-Testing ideas
-Pitching
-Disruption Technology
-Intellectual Property
-Chicken-and-Egg

The contents are quite interesting imo, but please don't think it is an IS course. It has nothing to do with technology, you should treat it as a CC course instead.

The actual teaching deviates from the syllabus quite a lot, the actual dates of assignments release/submission and lecture topics are quite off from what has announced. If you want fo follow the lectures, you will have to go listen.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is a Korean. He is fun sometimes, and making jokes. On the other hand, he seems really "hea", he does not manage the participation well, also he does not really grade anything. He also manages the time poorly and he could not finish all the topics and often run overtime in class. He also has an accent but not too worse.

But I can tell he is knowledgeable in entreprenurship.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Case studies assignments
20% Participation
30% Group Start-up Pitching Project
20% Final Exam

Idk how he counted participation. There are more than 20 students answer questions every lesson, the TA sits at the front and looks forward, the professor jumps around and is unlikely recognise our face. No namecard, no parti card, and everyone just pretends having answered question at the end of each class and writes their names on a paper for Prof's grading.

Even worse, no any assignment, exam, nor the presentation got released with scores. It is literally a black hole, I submitted everything but got returned nothing -.- The professor even once missed the submission date to set up Canvas assignment for uploading the case studies, what a joke.

I got unknown in participation, unknown in case assignments, unknown in project, unknown in final exam, then got an A-

Very interesting case, i totally have no idea whether the grading is good or bad, lmao
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload. You will need to do a presentation at the end, but thats common. Several case studies are needed and perhaps they are the only workloads.

Final exam questions are vague af and I am not sure if studying helps. Yet, there will be some questions related to the cases so remember to digest all cases carefully even you did not do the previous case assignments seriously.

reviews.author: younowho
reviews.comment_content:
If you want to get a good grade, you need to answer questions, preferably every class! They were open-end questions so you wouldn't feel stressed to get the "right" answer.

There might be a 1-page reading at the end of the lecture. He would give you a couple of minutes and would encourage the class to discuss ideas based on it.

He started class right on time, not even 1 minute late.

There's a group project which asked students to prepare a pitch and business plan for a start-up idea to be launched in the Chinese/HK market. It could be any idea - exiting ones, or sth from your own. This business idea would be the core part of your group project for the rest of your semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The ideas about entrepreneurship and innovation were easy to understand. The prof explained them clearly with a lot of real-life examples.

Around 1 week before the Mid Term, he would post the lecture videos on Canvas.

For the group project, he was very willing to meet with students to discuss how to improve our presentation. He would post time slots on Canvas and you could sign up.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation 10%
Mid Term 40% (Mean: 84.9, SD: 7.5)
Group project 50%
(Breakdown:
- Elevator pitch: 5%
- Feasibility Analysis & Revised elevator pitch: 10%
- Final presentation 15%
- Project report 20%)

The format of the Mid-term was quite vague. There were a lot of short essay questions that would ask you the pros & cons of sth. I was quite confused as to how many points I shd write down.

You would be able to handle the Mid-term well if you studied the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderately heavy.

The group project required regular meetings with your groupmates. But overall, the elevator pitch and feasibility analysis were assignments that built up to the Final presentation and the Report, which was a word format of the presentation. I personally find these exercises quite repetitive.

reviews.author: Sonya
reviews.comment_content: Content is relatively easy to digest similar to ISOM 1380. Majority is theory based and he uses real life case studies every class.
reviews.comment_teaching: By far one of my favourite professors at HKUST. Always very approachable and so efficient in terms of keeping to the schedule. Also he's very engaging in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is pretty good. Participation and attendance is a must if you want to get into the A range. If he remembers your name then that's definitely a good sign.

Mean was relatively high for the midterm so memorising key words per concept is important to get those full marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
Midterm is 40% and there is no final at all. The midterm was relatively easy, and if you pay attention in class and know the concepts then you should be fine.

One project is needed focused on a technology startup to pitch to the class. Includes 3 presentations and 1 final report. Requires a few meetings for group project.

Also make sure you discuss with him prior to the first presentation to finalise the product you want to pitch,  he will voice his concerns and you can address that in your pitch.

reviews.author: Ori
reviews.title: Good Course, Good Teaching
reviews.comment_content: Really engaging content generally, sometimes the theory can get a bit repetitive and boring but in general very enjoyable content!
reviews.comment_teaching: Best professor hands down, each class is engaging and thats down to him.
reviews.comment_grading: He is a fair grader, if you contribute in class discussions and do the basic level of work you should be fine! Midterm and final but he goes out of his way to help students prepare. Mid term and Final require a bit of memorisation but if you attend lectures you should be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is average. Group project requires both presentation and report. This should not take more than a few meetings and preparation for the presentation. In terms of content, there is quite a bit to memorise however - the exams are non cumulative.
